quiz.title: AP Physics 2
quiz.subtitle: Unit 2, Quiz 5: Thermodynamic Cycles & Kinetic Theory Applications
quiz.subject: Physics
quiz.topic: Constant volume processes, rms speed, PV diagrams, thermodynamic cycles, work calculations, heat exchange, thermal conduction, isothermal vs adiabatic processes

questions.question: A mole of ideal gas at STP is heated in an insulated constant volume container until the average velocity of its molecules doubled. Its pressure would therefore increase by what factor?
questions.explanation: Insulated constant volume ⇒ ΔV = 0. From kinetic theory: $v_{rms} \propto \sqrt{T}$. Doubling $v_{rms}$ ⇒ T increases by factor 4. At constant V and n, P ∝ T ⇒ P increases by factor 4.

questions.question: A sample of gas was first compressed from $V_1$ to $V_2$ at a constant pressure of $P_1$. The sample was then cooled so that the pressure went from $P_1$ to $P_2$ while the volume remained constant at $V_2$. Finally the sample was allowed to expand from $V_2$ back to $V_1$ while the pressure increased from $P_2$ back to $P_1$ as shown in the diagram. Which of the following statements are correct? Select two answers.
options: The area A represents the energy that is lost by the gas in this cycle.
The area A + D represents the '+' work done on the gas during the first compression.
The area D represents the '+' work done on the gas during the final expansion.
There was no energy lost or gained by the gas in this cycle.
questions.explanation: For the cycle: (1) Compression at P₁: work on gas = area A+D. (2) Cooling at V₂: W = 0. (3) Expansion along diagonal: work by gas = area A+D. Net work = enclosed area A (counterclockwise) = work done on gas. By first law (ΔU=0 for cycle), net heat out = area A = energy lost by gas.

questions.question: One end of a metal rod of length $L$ and cross-sectional area $A$ is held at a constant temperature $T_1$. The other end is held at a constant $T_2$. Which of the statements about the amount of heat transferred through the rod per unit time are true? Select two answers.
options: The rate of heat transfer is proportional to $A$.
The rate of heat transfer is proportional to $1/(T_1 - T_2)$.
The rate of heat transfer is proportional to $L$.
The rate of heat transfer is proportional to $(T_1 - T_2)$.
questions.explanation: Steady-state heat conduction rate: $\frac{Q}{t} = k A \frac{T_1 - T_2}{L}$, where $k$ is thermal conductivity. Thus, $\frac{Q}{t} \propto A$ and $\frac{Q}{t} \propto (T_1 - T_2)$, and inversely proportional to $L$.

questions.question: On all of the pV diagrams shown below the lighter curve represents isothermal process, a process for which the temperature remains constant. Which dark curve best represents an adiabatic process?
questions.explanation: For expansion: Isothermal: $PV = \text{constant}$, Adiabatic: $PV^\gamma = \text{constant}$ with $\gamma > 1$. Since $\gamma > 1$, the adiabatic curve is steeper than the isothermal curve when starting from the same point. The dark curve in option C falls below the isothermal curve as volume increases, correctly representing adiabatic expansion.

scoreMessages.90: Mastery: You understand kinetic theory relationships, PV cycle analysis, thermal conduction, and isothermal vs adiabatic processes!
scoreMessages.70: Solid grasp: Review the meaning of area in PV diagrams, the First Law for cycles, heat conduction formula, and PV^γ relationships.
scoreMessages.50: Needs review: Focus on $v_{rms} \propto \sqrt{T}$, work = area under PV curve, $\frac{Q}{t} = kA\Delta T/L$, and steeper adiabatic curves.
scoreMessages.0: Start with basics: At constant V, P∝T. Net work in cycle = enclosed area. Heat flow ∝ A, ΔT, 1/L. Adiabatic: steeper than isothermal on PV diagram.
